pages.text: Cocker Spaniels have two genes that affect how they look, the B Locus and the D Locus. The B Locus determines whether the dog has red or black fur, while the D Locus may dilute the dog's coloration. A rare variant of red fur that darkens the fur to brown has also been seen.

The B Locus has two potential alleles, the dominant 'B' and the recessive 'b'. The 'B' allele creates red fur, while the 'b' allele creates black fur. Dogs with one copy of 'b' will carry the black trait and may pass it on to pups, providing the potential for black pups depending on the other parent. Dogs with two copies of 'b' will always create either black carriers or black puppies.
pages.title: B Locus

pages.text: The D Locus has two potential alleles, the dominant 'D' and the recessive 'd'. The 'D' allele does not affect the coat's color, while the 'd' allele is a dilute that creates pale fur, called buff on red dogs and silver on black dogs.
pages.title: D Locus

pages.text: Dogs with one copy of 'd' will carry the dilution trait and may pass it on to pups, providing the potential for diluted pups depending on the other parent. Dogs with two copies of 'd' will always create either dilute carriers or diluted puppies.
pages.title: D Locus Cont.

pages.text: Some dogs have a trait that makes their red fur darker than normal, turning it to a chocolate brown. This trait will only show on red dogs, creating brown. Genetically, this trait isn't understood enough to show on tests, but it can be passed from parents to their pups.
pages.title: Brown Variant
